name: Looking for advice to make a powerful and fast leveling fighter.
author: StreI0k

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
StreI0k wrote: Wouldn't it be better going Fighter/Bard/PM though?

Still i'd like suggestions about how to do a powerleveling Fighter/WM
Better, no. Different, yes. So much depends on how you like to play - or whether you want to try a different playstyle. There is, after all, no "perfect" build - and it would probably be very boring if there was.

Certainly, for offense, a strength-based Fighter/WM is great, but saves and AC will likely suck (particularly Will, which can be catastrophic for mundane melee builds), and you won't have many skills to use. Plus, of course, qualifying for WM eats up a lot of (largely useless) feats, so you become more restricted in your options. If going for a Fighter/WM you'll certainly want a third class to help with these issues, such as - but not restricted to - Rogue, Bard or Monk. That will, of course, mean the loss of at least 1AB, but it's worth it not to be turned into a messy splat on the floor on a regular basis.

For a great straight-up meleer, also have a look at Mick's Brawler Champion in the 20s section - I've enjoyed that many times, along with its more exalted Epic cousin. Then there's Valerfor's Peck'n Decker, which is a Fighter 10/ WM 7/ Monk 3.

Cheers

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content:
Crits are great if it's easy to hit enemies, so it probably works from that side. It's less good on defence though and you don't have as many spare Feats to help, because WM requires so many. Further, you need at least 13 in Dex & Int (neither of which you really need), so you necessarily have less to put in Con (I assume maxing Str whatever).

On Fighter/Bard/PM you have the AC, but you don't have the Str, plus PM is low BAB. We don't want a caster here and in any case you would have to juggle Armor, due to ASF. I don't think it really works with the level restriction.

Oddly enough the topic of one of these builds on a low magic worlds was raised in dragon-spawn-fighter-6-bard-4-red-drago ... 15343.html way back in 2011. Kail's advice seems fairly sensible to me: 
I'd probably go Bard 3/FTR 7/RDD 10 preepic, then FTR 8 at 21st lvl to grab EWF/EWS and finish it off with Bard 4 for a final skilldump. In a low magic environment the extra +2 AB/+4 dmg is a big bonus

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
The three options you mention are among my personal favourites - and they give you so much scope in your builds.

As to your questions:

i) Afraid my timing is still a bit rubbish with CS, but you want to get one in during the first flurry of each round if you're using it (like KD), because your AB will drop thereafter until the next round starts. It's also more tactical than KD, so you need to decide whether you want to slow them down (leg) or knacker their use of weaponry (arm).

ii) Unless you're going big in Heal, in my opinion that's the least useful (assuming you're not going for a Cleric/Pally build). If possible, you always want a detection skill (Spot or Listen), and if you ain't got a handy Rogue nearby, not being blown to pieces on a frequent basis is a helpful thing.

iii) Nothing wrong with Dodge, but unless it's a necessary qualification for something else, you might want to think if anything else would be better (after all, it's +1AC only against the foe you're facing, so a bit rubbish with mobs).

iv) Roleplay UMD? It's a phenomenal skill to have, if you can get it. Use of scrolls, wands, and otherwise unavailable gear (assuming no clashes with specific items) - what's not to like? Rogues wearing Monk boots and robes while chucking spells around confuses the crap out of people!

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Well, if your build is Ftr/Rog/CoT then you might as well take dodge too, they have so many feats available that they need to burn them somewhere...
The only time you have some reason not to take it is when you leave your dexterity to 9 because you start with almost max strength & constitution for an EDR III build.
Or maybe try to have 14 charisma instead to take advantage of divine wrath's boost.

In short, if you start with 13 dexterity or above & you play a Ftr/Rog/CoT then you can also take dodge without compromising the build.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
This is just a quickie, as I have to call an ageing mother. But, if you split Rogue to levels 2 or 7/ 7 or 12/ and17 you'll get your Tumbles sorted more efficiently. And you may have said before why you're going for Bastard Sword, but I can't remember. If you bin it for Scimitar your chance of a crit soars and you get another feat (assuming you want to continue as human). I'm afraid I don't see the point of Great Cleave unless you can get to Dev Crit - it can be really annoying otherwise. Called Shot is an interesting take - I may be more tempted by Disarm - but that would only really work well with a 2-handed weapon. Fortunately, if you skip exotic weapons and Great Cleave, you can get WF and WS in Heavy Flail or Greatsword.

The taunt issue is an interesting one: take the skill and you can do it - take concentration and others won't be able to taunt you. (And you will have more skill points if you use tumble appropriately).

Sorry, have to dash...

posts.author: Valkos
posts.content:
I was typing during last night some of the same ideas, as Stag.

A few things to add would be Called Shot. You have improved expertise and since you do, I would skip it all together. Called Shot really shines early on and mostly with a ranged character.

On the topic of taunt, I would take it, but know this. Many mobs have concentration. If you ever want to create a taunt version of this kind of build, I would go for ftr6/bard4/cot10. You would lose sneak atks against knocked and flanked targets, but you would also gain more will saves and the ability to take bard at the last level of level 20.

Depending on how much you need saves on your character, I would take Luck of heroes and Strong soul at level 1.

In terms of feats, I would optimize as well for stronger early game power.


01: Fighter(1): LoH, S.Soul, Power Attack,
02: Fighter(2): Cleave
03: Fighter(3): WF: +
04: Fighter(4): Weapon Specialization: +
05: Bard(1)
06: Bard(2): knockdown
07: Bard(3): (Tumble, taunt 10)
08: CoT(1)
09: CoT(2): Improved Knockdown, Improved Critical: Bastard Sword

This is just a suggestion of course, but the main theme for any melee build in my mind early on is getting cleave, ikd and imp crit as soon as I can. I would follow the same logic on the rogue version of the build as well.

In general I believe your build comes down to the first 2 levels. If you can quite easily get to level 2, the I would take the LoH and S.soul all day. If not, I would keep LoH and take pwr atk and cleave level 1.

Last thing is I would also pick scimitar 100%. You will see the difference as your AB gets better. In the meantime, use whatever you find. Also the need for a blunt weapon should be for undeads of course, yet I dont see the need to specialize in it. The dmg lost from a slash/pierce weapon against undead, is clearly covered by blunt dmg alone.
